FacilityName: Al & John, Inc., dba Glenrock Hams

_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Process area detectors also located within roof top units

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Name: Al & John, Inc., dba Glenrock Hams

EPA ID: 100000217605



October 21, 2016



Executive Summary



Al & John, Inc., dba Glenrock Hams, (A&J) has designed a meat processing facility (NAICS code 311612 - Meat Processed from Carcasses) in West Caldwell, Essex County, New Jersey. In order to reach and maintain the temperatures required by the USDA standards, A&J utilizes a closed circuit anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system. The ammonia (anhydrous) (CAS#7661-41-7) is stored entirely within the refrigeration system. Anhydrous ammonia is subject to the requirements of the TCPA, OSHA, PSM, and EPA 112R (40 CFR 68). A&J has identified the EHS stationary source and has prepared its policies and programs accordingly.



I.    Stationary Source Identification



A&J has identified the use of anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant in a closed circuit refrigeration system as the only stationary EHS source at the facility. The facility design was completed in accordance with ANSI/IIAR 2-2008 - Equipment, Design, and Installation of Closed Circuit Ammonia Mechanical Refrigerating Systems. The ventilation design was completed in accordance with ANSI/IIAR 2-2008 and IIAR Bulletin No. 111 - Ammonia Machinery Room Ventilation.



The design is for a typical anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system consisting of ammonia vessels, an evaporative condenser, compressors, evaporators, chillers, and a gas purger. The system is designed in order to ensure that no offsite impact can occur even in the worst case EHS release scenario.



II.    Emergency Response



In the event of a discharge, Al & John, Inc. will follow emergency response protocols which include automatic shut-offs and the use of the emergency ventilation system. The emergency response plan will be coordinated with the Essex County, New Jersey Office of Emergency Management (OEM).



III.    Five Year History



The West Caldwell facility of Al & John, Inc. completed construction of the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration syst

em in December, 2012. This company has not had any accidental releases of ammonia (or any other EHS) in the last five years.



IV.    Accidental Release Prevention and Chemical Specific Prevention Procedures



Al & John, Inc. has developed standard operating procedures (SOPs) and a Risk Management Plan in accordance with NJAC 7:31 and 40 CFR 68. In addition, anhydrous ammonia detectors will be utilized as appropriate. Any one of the ammonia detectors will trigger an alarm in the control room and automatically implement equipment shut-down procedures as necessary.



In order to eliminate the possibility of an accidental release, all vessels containing anhydrous ammonia will be located in a diked vapor-tight containment room equipped with an ammonia sensor and a ventilation system. The containment room is designed to contain the total capacity of the largest ammonia vessel in the event of a release of anhydrous ammonia within this containment room. Emergency shut-down procedures will be implemented in this event.



V.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Al & John, Inc. has identified the hazards associated with the handling of anhydrous ammonia and has developed programs and systems to safeguard against these hazards. These procedures are subject to a management of change procedure, which allows the facility management to review and upgrade procedures and programs when necessary. A&J will continue to review the procedures and implement proactive solutions to health and safety concerns. There are no additional planned changes to improve safety associated with the handling of anhydrous ammonia at this time.
